subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|門|虫|ls=psc|c1=p|c2=s|t2=snake}}. The {{zh-l|*虫}} radical was a common component of the names of barbarians ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}), probably reflecting the Min people's worship of snakes ({{zh-ref|Li, 2017}}).

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
In most modern Min dialects and some other southern dialects (including Hakka and Xiang), it is read with a level tone ({{zh-l|*平聲}}), which is the expected reflex based on rime dictionaries. In Mandarin and the remaining southern dialects, it is read with a rising tone ({{zh-l|*上聲}}), probably due to analogy with the phonetic component of {{ltc-l|閔}} ({{zh-ref|Li, 2017}}).

{{etystub|zh}}
